head.title: Winds Blamed for Levels Of Mercury in Fish

hedline.hl1: Winds Blamed for Levels Of Mercury in Fish

abstract.p: Federal geologists and New York City environmental officials say same winds carrying pollutants from Midwest that cause acid rain in Adirondacks and Catskills appear to be cause of elevated levels of mercury in some fish in Neversink Reservoir in Sullivan County, NY (S)

block.p: The same winds carrying pollutants from the Midwest that cause acid rain in the Adirondacks and Catskills appear to be the cause of elevated levels of mercury in some fish in one of New York City's upstate reservoirs, according to Federal geologists and New York City environmental officials.

The New York State Department of Health is planning to issue an advisory next month warning anglers not to eat more than one meal a month of fish caught in the city's Neversink Reservoir, in Sullivan County, because mercury has been found in some fish in the reservoir at concentrations exceeding Federal limits.

The same winds carrying pollutants from the Midwest that cause acid rain in the Adirondacks and Catskills appear to be the cause of elevated levels of mercury in some fish in one of New York City's upstate reservoirs, according to Federal geologists and New York City environmental officials.

The New York State Department of Health is planning to issue an advisory next month warning anglers not to eat more than one meal a month of fish caught in the city's Neversink Reservoir, in Sullivan County, because mercury has been found in some fish in the reservoir at concentrations exceeding Federal limits.

The geologists and officials stressed that the mercury in the fish posed no risk to people drinking the water. No detectable levels of mercury have been found during regular monthly tests of water in the reservoir and tests in water mains in the city, said Charles Sturcken, the chief of staff of the New York City Department of Environmental Protection.

Nearby city reservoirs do not appear to have fish with elevated mercury levels, Mr. Sturcken said, possibly because they catch runoff from lower terrain that is less apt to capture wind-driven pollution.
